title: Creativity, Innovation and Revolution
paragraph:
Another couple of the useful useless websites I have made include: Mock JSON (https://the-mock-json-api.herokuapp.com/) and JS Injection Helper (https://floating-falls-21055.herokuapp.com/). I deemed both these websites revolutionary enough to warrant their own (free) domains - after about 2 minutes on Google, I have found existing alternatives for both sites.

The mock JSON site creates (as it claims) mocked JSON data from a template you input, it then gives you a URL endpoint to fetch the data and use in your site. I think whilst this website has about as much originality as a fidget spinner, it does differ from the alternatives. Similar solutions run locally, so you can use false data in the production of a site - my website on the other hand can be fetched from anywhere on the web! The use cases of this may be limited, but its important to find your niche. The lesson of this site was, consult the web before wasting time making a website thats only purpose is for this blog post that will never be read.

Ever found yourself attempting an XSS test, and need to send data back to an anonymous server? My JavaScript Injection Helper offers a solution to a problem that doesn't exist; you can send a GET request to the /injection_helper with the vital data. Quite enjoyed making the site, the whole site looks like you have a night mode on - that is the beauty of the site: send your requests day or night!

title: Exam paper parser project, untold genius
paragraph:
I have made too many (bad) websites. A couple of which I display at the top of the page. I think most of the websites follow a similar design theme; light pastel colours, soft borders, rounded shapes, ect. The websites featured on the websites are mainly made to improve my website designing skills (which is for the most part shocking) and therefore have almost no practical purpose.

However I have made a couple of functional websites, alongside some hobby websites. Among my "functional websites" I have a website designed called exam parser (http://exam-parser.infinityfreeapp.com/), where a user uploads a PDF of a exam paper and mark scheme, which the website converts into a usable online test. This sounds much more useful than it is - sadly it barely works with the paper I designed it around.

The first challenge is converting PDFs into readable data. As I was using a node JS server, I used a library which claimed to take a "snapshot" of the PDF, like if you opened a PDF and Ctrl A Ctrl C the whole document. Once again a good concept, but in reality you end up with a weird jumble of letters where tables have been converted directly into text. I persevered and used different complicated arrays of regEX on the string recursively until I ended up with an object that kinda represented the hierarchy of questions (1 > a > i, b > i, ii, c, ect.), and then display this hierarchy on the site. However, PDF papers and mark schemes are the most irregular documents - I would need both a masters in regular expressions and more time on my hands than a divorced 40 year old. So long story short, the website will probably not help your GCSEs.

title: Tab users, is it worth it?
paragraph:
Reading blog posts and watching youtube videos, it seems website developers spend 90% of their energy on supporting tab users for Grandad Accesibility.

Is this really worth it? Seems like alot of faff considering the sorta people who use tab to operate a website, aren't gonna get much use out of "What bread am I?" Buzzfeed quizes. I think web developers should start targeting their audience, by reducing the functionality of the page.

Your websites for the youds of today? Make the text tiny - to prevent gazes of senile eyes. You making a website for diet planning? Make the buttons tiny - so fat fingers isn't getting involved.
